NOTES

(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.
This  Report  was  prepared  by  a  team  consisting  of:  Axel  Weber,  Social

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Pakistan’s Interim Poverty Reduction Paper gives high priority to 
improving  health  and  education  outcomes  and  reducing  malnutrition  among  women  and 
children. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is assisting the Government with early childhood 
development (ECD), including in the health, education, rural development, agriculture, and 
financing sectors. ADB and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) also helped the 
Government explore ways of reducing rampant malnutrition.1 ADB is also planning to pilot a 
project to improve the health and nutrition status of marginalized women and children. The 
Government has requested, and ADB has agreed, to include a loan for an ECD project for 2003 
in the Country Strategy and Program for Pakistan. One of the three pillars of the Country 
Strategy and Program 2002–2004 is socially inclusive development, which will be strongly 
supported by the proposed project. 
 
2.  The Fact-Finding Mission visited Pakistan from 8 July to 19 July 2002. The Government 
and the Mission reached an understanding on the objectives, scope, cost estimates, financing, 
and implementation arrangements for the TA.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Almost  half  of  Pakistani  households  fall  below  the  poverty  line,  with  a  higher 
concentration  in  rural  areas,  and  poverty  increased  in  the  past  decade.  Low  human 
development status and insufficient social services have contributed to poverty. Because of the 
social structure and customs in Pakistan, women and girls have suffered even more due to less 
access to nutrition, education, health care, and employment. As a result fertility and maternal, 
infant, and child mortality remain high, while literacy, school enrollment, and school performance 
remain well below targets.  
 
4.  Nutrition.  About 40% of children under the age of 5 years are either moderately or 
severely underweight, implying that Pakistan has 8 million malnourished children. Malnutrition 
accounts for more than half of the under-five deaths in the country. About 42% of children under 
5 years are anemic due to poor diet and infections. Calorie, iron, and iodine deficiencies are the 
major nutrition problems. Data on low birth weight, drawn from hospital surveys and thus 
probably an underestimate, suggest a prevalence rate of about 25–30%, a figure that has 
remained virtually unchanged since the 1980s and is one of the highest in the world.  
 
5.  The main reason for the malnutrition in Pakistan is poverty (Appendix 1). This counts 
especially for rural areas, where people do not have enough food or if there is food, it is lacking 
basic micronutrients. Frequent illnesses and poor childcare also contribute to malnutrition.  
 
6.  Growth failure starts early in childhood among Pakistani children. The prevalence of 
underweight within an age group tends to increase over time. There is no significant gender 
differential in underweight prevalence but there is a rural-urban differential, with the prevalence 
among rural children being significantly higher than that among urban children (41.6% versus 
34.5%). Disturbing data from a resurvey of households in four districts (after 15 years) show no 
improvement in child nutrition: by the time a child reaches age 5, he or she has a 45% chance 
of being underweight, 62% probability of being stunted, and 12% chance of being severely 
stunted. (Insufficient breastfeeding, poor diet, and diarrhea prevalence are the main causes.)

These are very high levels of chronic malnutrition among children, and unless corrected will 
continue to depress learning, earning, and economic growth in Pakistan. Although no national 
data are available on weight gain by pregnant women, hospital data suggest the average is 
about 6 kilograms, half the recommended gain. Data from two national surveys suggest that 
chronic energy deficiency, iron deficiency anemia, and deficiencies of iodine and vitamin A are 
the most common nutrition problems in women of childbearing age. Iron deficiency anemia is 
one of the leading causes of high maternal mortality and poor psychomotor and cognitive skills 
in children. Iodine deficiency affects half the population not using iodized salt, resulting in 
serious mental and physical deficiencies. Low birth weight is mainly due to poor nutrition in girls 
and women of reproductive age. Early childhood malnutrition results in high mortality, morbidity, 
and  disability,  and  long-term  intellectual  and  physical  deficits  in  those  who  survive.  The 
economic  costs  of  maternal  and  child  malnutrition  are  also  high:  productivity  losses  are 
estimated to be at least 3% of gross domestic product annually, and cognitive losses in early 
childhood lead to lifelong losses of learning and earning. 
 
7.  Health Status. The health of mothers and children in Pakistan is among the worst in 
Asia. The maternal mortality ratio is about 500 per 100,000 live births; infant mortality is about 
85, but is worse in poor rural areas, and much worse when mothers are illiterate, testifying to 
the importance of maternal education in improving child health and welfare. Child under-five 
mortality follows the same pattern. The delivery of preventive health care at the community level 
is weak, but may improve if the cadre of lady health workers (LHWs) is increased. The number 
of LHWs should be raised to 100,000 from 70,000; but they must be provided with logistics to 
assess, treat, and refer children with severe or organic deficits that impede healthful functioning. 
 
8.  Health Care. Inequitable access leads to problems, especially for poor families and their 
children. Often there is little awareness of the specific health needs of children. Pakistan has a 
public  system  of  health  care  provision,  including  primary  and  secondary  care,  which  is 
supposed to be free of charge. However, most Pakistanis spend a large share of their income 
on health. Private expenditure is estimated to be three times the amount spent by the public 
sector. The private sector is rapidly expanding due to problems in the public sector, for example 
with absenteeism of staff and lack of drugs.  
 
9.  Education.  Schooling  remains  inequitably  distributed  among  income  groups  and 
provinces. Half the population is illiterate. Seven million children are out of primary school. 
Approximately 15% of boys and 50% of girls do not enter school. For many rural children, in 
particular girls, social and physical access to education remains a major problem. Remote 
schools often do not have a teacher. Among children who start primary school, there is a 50% 
drop out rate by the second year. This is partly caused by poor school performance. First grade 
is often overcrowded, and includes those who started schooling when over 6 years old, and 
younger  siblings  of  those  attending  school.  Children  are  ill  prepared  for  school  due  to 
inadequate preschool intellectual stimulus. Most schools do not have a kindergarten, and few 
children receive some form of education before they are 5 years old. Parents often are not 
aware of the education needs of children. 
 
10.  Early Childhood Development. Studies have shown that poor child care leads to 
increased  mortality  and  disability,  and  results  in  stunting,  poor  school  performance,  and 
intellectual underachievement. Providing a caring and stimulating environment for the young 
child needs to be done at household level and cannot be achieved through institutional service 
delivery.  To  reach  household  levels,  especially  the  poor,  in  cost-effective  way  requires 
community-based  interventions  and  the  establishment  of  community-based  organizations 
(CBOs) to support social service efforts. While various community workers and teachers of

3 
government departments provide specific services at the community level, they do not have 
much  experience  supporting  CBOs  in  the  management  of  integrated  ECD  services.  The 
involvement  of  these  CBOs  can  be  best  promoted  through  elected  representatives,  local 
government,  and  specialized  agencies  like  rural  support  programs  and  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs). As the ECD concept is relatively new to Pakistan and therefore has no 
institutional  framework,  it  should  first  be  introduced  in  communities  that  already  have 
established CBOs that are involved in, for example, rural development programs. Once ECD 
interventions have been successfully implemented, they can be used as models and replicated 
in neighboring villages.  
 
11.  Government Services. The government provides an extensive network of education 
and health services. However, these services often do not reach those most in need, or reach 
them in a limited way. Vulnerable children under five, in particular those from poor rural families, 
are often not reached by conventional public services. The education system is supporting 
children from four years of age and above (including kindergarten). Health services often focus 
on curative care, while not addressing the underlying causes of ill health of children such as 
poor diet or hygiene. LHWs focus on a limited range of services reflecting the priority of national 
vertical programs. However, they give less attention to basic problems like unhygienic living 
conditions;  poor  diet;  poor  quality  drinking  water;  and  support  to  caregivers  for  child 
development  to  address  needs  of  intellectual,  social,  and  physical  stimulation.  Community 
leaders usually do not address these either, as child care is typically seen as a responsibility of 
the parents or extended family. The scale and impact of social services for the very poor 
through zakat (compulsory annual deduction for all Muslims in favor of the poor) is very limited. 
 
12.  NGOs. Many NGOs are active on all levels, at the central, provincial, and district levels, 
and several focus on child development. UNICEF is piloting an integrated ECD project in 30 
villages in Islamabad Capital Territory and awaits results to continue the intervention on a larger 
scale. NGOs such as the Aga Khan Foundation have an interest in expanding their early 
childhood education interventions to more comprehensive ECD programs where CBOs have 
been established in Sindh and Punjab. The Institute for Development Studies and Practices in 
Quetta provides technical support on capacity building in the social sector through CBOs. Sindh 
Education Foundation and Institute of Education Development (Aga Khan University) have 
extensive field operations and community experience. NGOs, especially at the grassroots level, 
will be crucial for any successful implementation of an ECD project. Each province has well-
organized  NGO  associations  that  may  be  tapped  for  particular  project  activities,  e.g., 
communications, training, and field research. The TA team will appraise this option, including 
the role of the National Commission for Child Welfare and Development and its provincial 
counterparts. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
13.  The  TA  will  assist  the  Government  in  preparing  a  project  to  develop  and  provide 
integrated ECD service delivery. The TA’s output will be a detailed project proposal including 
verifiable objectives, project activities, implementation arrangements, monitoring, and financing. 
The primary objective of the project being prepared by the TA is to improve the development 
conditions of children. The specific objectives of the project are to (i) reduce the prevalence of 
underweight, anemic, and stunted children; (ii) provide integrated service delivery in health, 
nutrition, and early education with community-based initiatives and better child care; and (iii)

4 
establish a support strategy that will improve the capacity of the local governments and NGOs 
to assist communities in the planning, financing, and monitoring of ECD activities.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  The TA will carry out a bottom-up feasibility study of the project in selected districts in all 
four provinces. It will explore alternative project interventions, involving all relevant government 
partners at the district, provincial, and central levels; communities; and target groups, starting 
with the lower level stakeholders. Special emphasis will be given to communities that have 
already established CBOs. 
 
15.  More  specifically,  the  TA  will  (i)  conduct  a  situation  analysis  including  all  ongoing 
projects and activities, especially those financed by other agencies and those supported by the 
Government in Pakistan; (ii) identify the best practices in Pakistan and elsewhere; (iii) define the 
scope of the sustainable ECD interventions that help to improve (a) the health and nutrition 
status and psychomotor, psychosocial, and cognitive development of young children; and (b) 
educational achievement and learning potential through life; (iv) identify possible partners and 
assess the institutional capacity of local governments, communities, and NGOs to manage and 
finance integrated ECD initiatives; (v) establish the quantitative framework and estimate costs of 
the  Project  to  ensure  effective  and  sustainable  systems  for  the  delivery  of  essential  child 
services; (vi) identify key program components including management and financing systems 
under the devolution process, programs to improve nutrition and learning ability of children, and 
caregivers’  knowledge  and  skills;  and  (vii)  identify  suitable  executing  and  implementing 
agencies for the Project. Detailed descriptions of the activities to be carried out during the TA 
are included in the outline terms of reference for consulting services in Appendix 2. 
 
16.  Given the lack of data on ECD, the TA should initiate an extensive baseline and follow-
up surveys, and provide for regular data collection/monitoring mechanisms. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent of which $335,000 will be 
foreign exchange, and $290,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will finance $500,000 
equivalent, which includes the entire foreign exchange costs and $165,000 equivalent in local 
currency costs. The remaining $125,000 equivalent will be contributed by the Government in 
kind  and  will  include  office  accommodation,  counterpart  staff  remuneration,  transportation, 
surveys, and workshops. The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis by the Japan Special 
Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
shown in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The TA will employ a process approach. It will focus on the provincial and district levels. 
Local  communities  and  target  groups  will  be  involved  throughout.  There  will  be  close 
coordination with other projects financed by ADB, other international agencies, and projects 
supported by the Government and local NGOs.  
 
19.  The Executing Agency will be the Ministry of Women Development, Social Welfare and 
Special Education (MWDSE). A steering committee will be created with representatives from 
MWDSE,  Economic  Affairs  Division,  Ministry  of  Health,  Ministry  of  Education,  Ministry  of 
Planning  and  Development,  Ministry  of  Population  Welfare,  Ministry  of  Finance,  and  the 
governments of the four provinces. The steering committee will be headed by MWDSE and will

5 
ensure  that  national  and  local  government-community  partnerships  form  the  basis  for 
proceeding in transparent and accountable fashion. Members of the steering committee will be 
appointed from central and provincial governments. All line agencies, provincial representatives, 
and communities must be involved throughout the planning and implementation. 
 
20.  ECD is a new field of Government services for which an institutional owner has to be 
identified. The TA will identify the most suitable institutional arrangements for the execution of 
the ensuing project; agreements will then be made with suitable implementing agencies at 
various levels.  
 
21.  ADB's Devolution Support Program3 and the ongoing Public Resource Management 
Program Loans4 (North-West Frontier Province and Sindh by World Bank, and Punjab by ADB) 
will form the basis for future social development initiatives of Government at all three levels 
(federal, provincial, and local) and therefore the TA should take into full consideration these 
important ongoing programs. 
 
22.  The TA will be carried out over 6 months, beginning in December of 2002 and ending in 
May 2003. There will be a total input of 35 person-months of experts, 25 from domestic and 10 
from international experts. The consulting team will include an ECD program specialist (co–
team leader, 5 person-months), an early childhood education specialist (3 person-months), and 
a  maternal  and  child  nutrition  specialist  (2  person-months)  as  international  consultants. 
Domestic consultants will include a management and institutional development specialist (co-
team-leader,  5  person-months),  a  maternal  child  health  specialist  (4  person-months),  four 
provincial  planning  advisers  (2  person-months  each),  a  social  development  and  social 
mobilization specialist (3 person-months), a poverty impact analyst (2 person-months), and a 
financial analyst and program evaluation economist (3 person-months). All consultants will be 
recruited  through  a  consulting  firm  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants, and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic 
consultants. The team will be coheaded by an international and a local project specialist (the 
ECD specialist and the management and institutional development specialist). 
 
23.  The consultants will submit four major reports: an inception report, no later than 3 weeks 
after fielding of the consultants; mid-term report, 3 months after TA inception; and a draft final 
report, 5 months after inception. The Government and ADB will comment on the draft final 
report. The final report will be submitted within 3 weeks after receiving comments. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for preparing the Early Childhood Development Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
 
The proposed project will help to reduce poverty by promoting human development among preschool children. 
 
The project will have several impacts in social and economic terms. It will (i) help to reduce the high economic costs of 
maternal and child malnutrition in terms of productivity losses, which can be estimated to be at least 3% of gross 
domestic product annually; (ii) reduce cognitive losses in early childhood, which lead to lifelong losses of learning and 
earning; (iii) reduce costs of health care; and (iv) contribute to higher levels of education in the country through higher 
school enrollment rates and lower dropout rates, and thus contribute to increased productivity and economic growth. 
 
To help the Government achieve its human development goals, the project preparatory technical assistance (TA) is 
giving high priority to improving access to health care and early education for children up to 6 years. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Classification:  Poverty Intervention 
 
The incidence of poverty in Pakistan increased from 26.6% in fiscal year (FY) 1993 to 32.2% in FY1999 and the 
number of poor increased by over 12 million people during this period. Since FY1999, economic growth has slowed 
further. Development spending has continued to decline, and it is likely that the incidence of poverty in Pakistan today 
is significantly higher than in FY1999. Poverty rose more sharply in the rural areas in the 1990s, and in FY1999 the 
incidence of rural poverty (36.3%) was significantly higher than urban poverty (22.6%). Inequality also increased in all 
four provinces, and FY1999 was clearly the most unequal year in all categories. In FY1997, the income share of the 
bottom 20% of households had declined to 6.9% from 7.9% in FY1987, and the income share of the bottom 40% of 
households declined from 20% to 18%. During the same period, the ratio of the share of the top quintile to that of the 
bottom quintile also increased to 6.5% from 5.2% for all areas. 
 
In general, the experience of poverty by men and women is different and unequal. It is increasingly evident that 
women bear a disproportionately high share of the burden of poverty within the family and the society.  
 
Education is the most important factor that distinguishes the poor from the non-poor. For example, the proportion of 
literate household heads in poor households is almost half that of non-poor households. Poor households on average 
have 75% more children than the non-poor households. Most of these children are not receiving any education, and 
thus the cycle of poverty is perpetuated. There is a strong correlation between household income and school 
enrollment. 
 
Health indicators in Pakistan have shown some improvement over the past decade, although they remain lower than 
indicators in other low-income countries. The infant mortality rate is estimated to have declined from 122 per 1000 live 
births in FY1991 to 89 per 1000 live births by FY1999 according to the Pakistan Integrated Household Survey (PIHS). 
The infant mortality rate was 93 per 1000 live births for males and 85 for females, while in urban areas it averaged 73 
per 1000 live births as opposed to 95 per 1000 live births for rural areas.  
 
Maternal mortality rates are also very high at about 340–400 per 100,000 births, largely because over 80% of total 
births take place at home, under the care of traditional birth attendants. Less than a third of expectant mothers 
typically go for prenatal checks, and this rate falls to barely a tenth for postnatal consultations.  
 
The PIHS for 1997–1998 reports some improvement in the total fertility rate, which had declined from 6.8 births per 
woman in the mid 1980s to about 5 births per woman by 1997. Once again, the bulk of the reduction appeared to have 
taken place in urban areas, and has been largely attributed to an increase in the use of contraceptives. The 
contraceptive prevalence rate is estimated to be about 29% for urban areas, one of the lowest in Asia. 
 
Full immunization rates increased from 45% to 49% based on recall measures; however, these fell considerably short 
of the 90% coverage targeted for 1998. Overall, the gender gap in this area was eliminated by FY1997, but 
reappeared in FY1999, when the difference in immunization between males and females was 7%. The rural/urban gap

narrowed from 9% to 6% over this time. The PIHS 1998–1999 data show a strong correlation between income and 
immunization as approximately three-quarters of children in the upper income quintile are fully immunized, but only 
one quarter are immunized in the bottom quintile.  
 
Three factors — communicable infectious diseases, reproductive health problems, and nutritional deficiencies —
account for almost 60% of the burden of disease in Pakistan, when measured in terms of life-years lost. All of these 
are preventable or easily treatable problems, but the quality of health services is so inadequate that the incidence of 
such diseases remains high, and mortality rates remain high. An estimated 70% of all health facilities are in urban 
areas, and 70% of the national public health budget is spent on the construction and maintenance of hospital facilities, 
while primary health care is under-financed. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Stakeholder Analysis  
 
The TA was developed through extensive consultation with central and local governments and stakeholders. To 
ensure local ownership of the project and the measures to be identified and subsequently carried out through the 
ensuing loan, the process of consulting with civil society and engaging all stakeholders in the development of the 
project must be continued. The TA will develop a strategy to define the participation of all stakeholders and determine 
their role and level of participation. This includes the role of the relevant ministries, local governance structures, and 
community-based organizations such as women’s groups as project effectiveness will depend, to a large extent, on 
the participation of women. Special efforts may be needed to engage poor women in the process. The TA will have to 
examine gender issues to make sure that women are fully involved in the project. For any community-driven 
components of the ensuing project loan, the participation process will be defined through the TA.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
1.  The consulting team will be recruited under a firm through the simplified procedure of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants. The specific technical tasks associated with each consultant are outlined below. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
(i)  Early  Childhood  Development  (ECD)  Program  Specialist  and  Co-Team 
Leader (5 person-months) 
 
2.  The specialist will prepare the technical assistance (TA) inception report; prepare the TA 
work program; consolidate TA outputs with the work program throughout the TA period; consult 
with the steering committee, the Executing Agency, and ADB; prepare and monitor ECD project 
preparatory  guidelines;  organize  and  prepare  proceedings  for  the  midterm  TA  review  and 
include them in the draft final report; prepare the draft final report, with required revisions for 
finalization based on the tripartite review; identify current child caring practices; recommend 
appropriate development assessment tools; evaluate potential partners; identify current and 
best practices in ECD; review national policies and plans for ECD initiatives; prepare project 
components;  advise  on  the  community  consultation  process;  and  set  up  and  work  with  a 
communications, social mobilization, and participation technical working group (TWG).  
 
  (ii)  Maternal and Child Nutrition Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
3.  The specialist will review national policy guidelines for nutrition and feeding practices; 
recommend a strategy; advise and recommend, if necessary, feasibility studies on feeding and 
nonfeeding options to improve nutritional status among pregnant women and children under 
five; and help set up and work with an integrated service delivery TWG. 
 
(iii)  Early Childhood Education (ECE) Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
4.  The specialist will examine the options for developing a union-based network of day care 
and  early  education  facilities;  prepare  with  the  integrated  service  delivery  TWG  a  project 
component; develop curriculum and training for parental education; identify current and best 
programs and practices in early childhood education; and identify and evaluate current pre-
primary  programs  in  the  public  sector  and  among  non-government  organizations  (NGOs) 
serving the poor. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
 
(i)  ECD Management and Institutional Development Specialist and Co-Team 
Leader (5 person-months) 
 
5.  The specialist will prepare a management plan for the project; set up a decentralized 
planning, management and information systems TWG; consolidate a set of project indicators; 
identify a support strategy to improve the capacity of local governments at provincial, district, 
and  union  levels,  and  of  local  NGOs,  to  assist  communities  in  planning,  financing,  and 
monitoring ECD activities; assess current capacity-building needs of local governments and 
NGOs; assess capacity-building resources; assist provincial planning teams in selection of 
partners; and assist planning teams to design monitoring and evaluation systems.

(ii)  Maternal and Child Health Specialist (4 person-months) 
 
6.  The specialist will review the Government’s child survival programs, assess maternal 
risks to health and survival, evaluate the feasibility of linking with other projects (such as 
Women’s Health and Reproductive Health), recommend communications strategies, design new 
management approaches for child health, recommend the use of indicators for decentralized 
monitoring of maternal and child health programs, guide and supervise feasibility studies, and 
work with the integrated service delivery TWG. 
 
(iii)  Social Development and Social Mobilization Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
7.  The specialist will assess the strategies for attaining effective community access; identify 
and evaluate community development projects; analyze poor communities’ experience with 
social sector services; evaluate the best information and communication channels; assist in 
identifying possible partners; conduct gender and indigenous population analyses; develop 
studies or conduct focus groups; using the profile of culturally distinct communities, address the 
acceptability of the project interventions; recommend strategies for social mobilization; and work 
with the communications, social mobilization, and societal participation TWG. 
 
(iv)  Provincial Planning Advisers (1 per province, 2 person-months each) 
 
8.  The  advisers  will  identify  key  component  activities,  best  partners,  and  best 
implementation and communication strategies in their provinces; identify strategies to support 
local governments and NGOs; identify areas for legislative and regulatory reform, institutional 
development, and capacity building at the provincial and national levels; identify key component 
activities for the project; identify partners for the project in all service areas; establish a strategy 
to support local governments and NGOs to assist communities in planning, financing, and 
monitoring ECD activities; recommend a specific monitoring and evaluation system for the 
project; and identify areas for legislative and regulatory reform, institutional development, and 
capacity building on the provincial and national levels. 
 
(v)  Poverty Impact Analyst (2 person-months) 
 
9.  The analyst will prepare a poverty impact assessment; prepare a poverty profile; identify 
the potential beneficiaries; work with the social development and social mobilization specialist 
on  gender  and  indigenous  population  issues;  quantify  the  poverty  impact  of  the  project 
interventions; work with the financial analyst to estimate unit benefits to units costs received; 
estimate  the  poverty  impact  ratio;  identify  risks  of  failure  to  achieve  the  project's  poverty 
objectives,  and  steps  to  be  taken  to  minimize  those  risks;  identify  project  performance 
indicators;  and  take  into  account  relevant  ADB  handbooks  and  guidelines  for  conducting 
economic and poverty impact analyses. 
 
(vi)  Financial Analyst and Program Evaluation Economist (3 person-months) 
 
10.  The  economist  will  prepare  a  comprehensive  analysis  that  supports  the  economic 
justification of the project; coordinate the collection of data; provide cost estimates for all ECD 
project components together with the poverty impact analyst; analyze existing pilot initiatives in 
ECD funded by other agencies, regarding cost-effectiveness, least cost principle, and poverty 
impact; and take into account relevant ADB handbooks and guidelines for conducting economic 
and poverty impact analyses.

10  Appendix 2 
C.  Technical Working Groups 
 
11.  The team of specialists will be advised by three TWGs, composed of local experts and 
stakeholders: (i) a communications, social mobilization, and societal participation TWG; (ii) an 
integrated  service  delivery  TWG;  and  (iii)  a  decentralized  planning,  management,  and 
information systems TWG. The TWGs will advise on the preparation of the related project 
components; advise on the design of the project activities; advise on the identification of target 
groups  and  communities;  review  and  comment  on  documents  and  plans  prepared  by  the 
specialist; advise on institutional arrangements for the implementation of the project; facilitate 
contacts with stakeholders and NGOs; advise on impacts of project activities pertinent to the 
Pakistani situation and environment; and help disseminate and communicate project objectives 
and activities to stakeholders and the public. Each TWG will elect a chairperson. The TWGs will 
meet at least three times upon request by the chairperson in consultation with the team leader.
